ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This is a 1 credit course. Speakers every lecture. Some good, some you don't care for the subject matter or simply have better things to do with your time. You only have to do the readings for the topic on which you are going to write the paper. While the other readings are required for class discussion, I am going to guess most people don't read them.
I think I was expecting to get more out of this course-- I wanted to hear more lectures from Prof. Nolon...
10. This class fills a great little niche at FES- a glimpse into law, zoning, and planning and how they all fit together. The guest speakers are top notch.
Great course, great selection of speakers
I highly recommend this course to those who are interested in learning from professionals in the urban planning field.

This seminar course did not fit into the regular structure that many of these questions apply to. It was a great series of speakers however. I am very glad I participated, though it would have been helpful if there had been more of a trajectory of subjects covered throughout the semester. Of course, this is probably nearly impossible as speakers came based on their availability, but it would probably have been helpful if there was a little more structure to this seminar.
Prof. Nolon. He is an authority on land use issues, brought in some great speakers, and is a great overall professor.
Wide range of topics covered
Easy credit.This is the closest approximation to course content on urban planning, which Yale lacks big time.
There were different guest speakers every week. This gave students the opportunity to learn about how a variety of organizations are approaching land use planning today.
Great coverage of cutting-edge issues in land use planning and policy.
The opportunity to learn about a diverse set of land use planning projects from professionals in the land use development field.

1. Professor Nolon's lecture on the last day of class was outstanding. I wish he had given more lectures.2. The readings were great and the speakers as well- it is informative and entertaining to be able to show up each weak and have an expert in the field come to chat for one hour.3. Jonathan Rose's visit a highlight.
The range of presenters was great.
It was an honor and a pleasure to get to learn about land use planning from Professor Nolon and the speakers he invited to class.

- The professor's clear and evident dedication that each and every student learn more about the land use planning field- The guest speakers were amazing- The variety of topics were diverse and all students could find something that was of interest- The variety of presentation styles made coming to class always interesting- The more intermediate/advanced levels at which guest speakers spoke (I'm very happy that the professor advised speakers to just "jump into" their presentations. This meant that there was very little repeat between weeks.)
Really nice to hear from so many speakers working in the field.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: None.
Maybe have students vote on the value of the topics/speakers. For future classes, eliminate the speakers/topics least preferred by students.A field trip within New Haven would be great.
This class was average. Many of the speakers talked about the same issues so there was a lot of redundancy.
Some of the speakers should develop shorter presentations so that students could ask more questions about their work.
It could be a little bit longer- I often felt that we were a little rushed.

I think the course needs to be more credits and have more content. It could be so much more! With more credits, there could be classes that didn't have presenters but focused instead on discussion with the professor and students.
More time for discussion
N/A. This class is excellent.
- I only wish that this course had more sessions

The speakers usually spoke for the entire class time, not leaving much time for discussion or engagement. Students would be able to get more out of the class if the presentations were kept to 30-40 minutes tops.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Sufficient
Claire is great.
The TA was available and responsive.
I never asked for help - not sure how to answer this.

Our TA was very helpful in keeping us informed about the class schedule and arranging activities.The instructor was very willing to discuss my professional goals and development. He also offered his time and expertise to assist me on a research project regarding land use planning and sustainable development.

1. Professor Nolon is not particularly available, but he was always very willing to stay after class and talk about any topic.2. Claire was amazing- responsive to email, helpful, and sharp organizationally.
I never needed them but they seemed available and willing to help. John Nolon is passionate about teaching this subject.
Professor Nolon's availability and responsiveness were excellent.
Both the instructor and the TA were extremely helpful!

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am interested in urban planning and transportation, and there are two few courses offered at Yale about this subject matter. Development patterns have huge environmental implications and urban studies should have a larger place in FES.
I was hoping for more energy related subject matter, which there is little of.

Theoretically it would make sense with my program but I had already learned everything - I didn't learn anything new in this class apart from regional planning efforts that are specific to the northeast. In terms of general applied principles, I didn't learn new material.
This course helps me to understand the urban-rural interface and how land use planning affects our decisions in both.
My focus is on urban ecosystem services and green infrastructure and this class was a great complement to my other courses.
Land use planning is highly relevant to my overall studies.
This course filled a gap at FES by giving students the opportunity to much more about the land use planning field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in land use planning issues
Fits with my interests
Easy credit.And to gain an understanding of urban planning issues.
To learn more about land use planning.
I am interested in land use policy and law.
I wanted to learn more about sustainable development and land use planning.
I wanted to learn a little bit about land use planning.
I wanted to take a course with Professor Nolon and also to get a look into how law/regulation is mode and implemented.
Land use planning is pivotal to urban ecosystem function.
I was excited by this opportunity to learn about cutting edge issues from leaders and trailblazers in the field.
To learn more about urban planning
It was a good introduction to the field of land use planning.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, and more
Yes
No. Lectures/speakers not very interesting, only a few that I liked enough to engage in conversations.
Yes
I had heard great reviews about this class but I would say for me, it wasn't that helpful. Maybe for someone who knows nothing about land use planning it would be useful.S
Yes.
Sure
Yes.Professor Nolon's wrap uplecture and brainstorming session was particularly great.
yes.
Exceeded expectations
Absolutely.
Absolutely exceeded by expectations!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, and more
Yes
Yes
See question 17.
Yes. In fact, I found the concepts and projects discussed in class so interesting that I'm now pursuing similar job-related opportunities.
Yes. I would have also like more focused readings with a better background.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Enjoy it.
Don't get your hopes up too high.
This is a fun course that introduces you to the ways that different organizations are approaching land use planning.
It's only 1 credit and 1 hr per week - it's worth taking.
Attend a dinner with the speaker and instructor. It offers a great opportunity to discuss your professional goals with leaders in the field.
1. Show up early and talk with the speakers.2. Do your response paper early.3. Ask Professor Nolon more questions, even if you feel silly and out of your league.
The class is what you make of it. It's totally undemanding which is in some ways a shame because if it were more demanding, we'd get more out of it.
This class is a great overview of current land use planning issues and includes numerous practical examples from practitioners as well as networking opportunities - I highly recommend this course.
Take advantage of the readings and the networking that the speakers offer.
